He deals on a regular basis with the heartache and regret that accompany abusing the body by violating the law of chastity and the Word of Wisdom – both designed to protect our bodies and our spirits. I plead with you to pay attention to Elder Bednar’s words of warning. If you do so, you will bless not only your life, but the lives of those who you love on this side of the veil and those whose spirits are waiting to come to earth as your future mortal sons and daughters.

 

2. We ARE accountaBLE for decisions we make about our spiritual attributes

One of President Monson’s favorite poems highlights one of the spiritual attributes needed by all of us:

 

“I have wept in the night at my shortness of sight

That to other’s need made me blind

But I never have yet had a twinge of regret

For being a little too kind.”4


Kindness is one of the essential spiritual attributes we each need to acquire in this life. In our efforts to obtain spiritual attributes, we should expect that significant sacrifices will be required of us. Just as you have made great sacrifices and have been required to pay tuition to obtain your intellectual education, your quest to become like the Savior in acquiring the spiritual attributes that He has, also has a cost.

 

In Jesus’ day, he was approached by a lawyer who asked “Master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?”5 What followed was one of the most memorable parables the Savior taught.

 

“…A certain man went down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and fell among thieves, which stripped him of his raiment, and wounded him, and departed, leaving him half dead. And by chance there came down a certain priest that way; and when he saw him, he passed by on the other side. And likewise a Levite, when he was at the place, came and looked on him, and passed by on the other side. But a certain Samaritan, as he journeyed, came where he was; and when he saw him, he had compassion on him, and went to him, and bound up his wounds, pouring in oil and wine, and set him on his own beast, and brought him to an inn, and took care of him. And on the morrow when he departed, he took out two pence, and gave them to the host, and said unto him, Take care of him; and whatsoever thou spendest more, when I come again, I will repay thee.”

 

Jesus then paused and asked the poignant question, “Which now of these three, thinkest thou, was neighbour unto him that fell among the thieves? And he [the lawyer who had asked the question that prompted the parable] said, He that shewed mercy on him. Then said Jesus unto him, Go and do thou likewise.”6

 

Several years ago, President Monson read a letter sent to the First Presidency telling about a couple of church members who served as good Samaritans to a man in need who was just passing through Salt Lake City. In his hurry to flee a bad situation in Boston, he had forgotten his necessary medication and found himself sick and trembling from loss of sleep and his lack of his much-needed medication. In part the letter read:

 

…”In the…hotel restaurant, I sat dejectedly…Out of the corner of my eye I saw a couple approach my table. ‘Are you all right, young man?’ the woman asked. I raised up, crying and a bit shaken, and related my story and the predicament I was in then. They listened carefully and patiently to my nearly incoherent ramblings, and then took charge…They spoke with the restaurant manager, then told me I could have all I wanted to eat there for five days. Then they drove me to a clinic and saw that I was provided with the medications I needed – truly my basic lifeline to sanity and comfort.

“…On my last day at the hotel, before I resumed my journey, I turned in my key; and there was a message for me from that couple: ‘Repay us by showing gentle kindness to some other troubled soul along your road.’ That was my habit, but I determined to be more keenly on the lookout for someone who needed a lift in life.

 

The letter closed with the following words:

 

“…I don’t know if these are indeed the ‘latter-days’ spoken of in the scriptures, but I do know that two members of your Church were saints to me in my desperate hours of need. I just thought you might like to know.”

 

May we, like this couple of modern-day good Samaritans, be willing to make the needed sacrifices in order to become more like the Savior – filled with spiritual attributes such as kindness and selflessness.

 

3. We ARE accountAble for how we honor God’s pattern for marriage and family

What is HIS pattern? We find God’s pattern for marriage and the family in the inspired document “The Family: A Proclamation to the World.” When this proclamation was read by President Gordon B. Hinckley in a General Relief Society Meeting in 1995, the world was different than it is today. Because the Lord sees all things as they were, are and will be, He revealed this sacred document to define His pattern for marriage. This pattern serves as a guide for us as we make our way along the covenant path amidst those who ridicule, mock and seek to distract us as they jeeringly point fingers of scorn at us from the great and spacious building. I invite you to memorize this sacred document, “The Family: A Proclamation to the World.” As you do, I promise that God’s pattern for marriage and family will be planted deep in your hearts. We have been told by a prophet, seer and revelator that we will be asked to account for how we honored God’s pattern for marriage and family. First we need to know the pattern in order to honor it!

 

One of the many phrases I love in this inspired proclamation says, “Husband and wife have a solemn responsibility to love and care for each other…” This, too, often requires sacrifice, kindness and selflessness on our part.

 

For those who are not married or who are without families, this means preparing to become worthy spouses and loving fathers and mothers. In some cases these blessings will not be fulfilled until the next life, but the ultimate goal and promised blessings are the same for all providing covenants have been faithfully kept.7

 

Because Christmas is just around the corner, I’d like to share with you the essence of one of my favorite Christmas stories that illustrates the beautiful phrase in the proclamation about loving and caring for each other as husband and wife.

 

Many of you are familiar with this story. It tells of a young married couple who dearly love each other. Like many of you, they are living on next to nothing and find themselves the day before Christmas with very little money to buy gifts for each other. Because of their love for each other, they sacrifice their most prized possessions in order to buy gifts of love for each other. She sells her beautiful long hair to purchase a chain for his pocket watch – the only worldly possession of worth that he owns. Unfortunately, he sells his pocket watch to buy some decorative combs for her beautiful long hair – which she has cut too short to hold the beautiful combs.

 

O. Henry, the author concludes the story by saying, “The Magi, as you know, were wise men – wonderfully wise men – who brought gifts to the Babe in the manger. They invented the art of giving Christmas presents. Being wise, their gifts were no doubt wise ones. And here I have lamely related to you the uneventful story of two foolish children in an apartment who most unwisely sacrificed for each other the greatest treasures of their house. But in a last word to the wise of these days, let it be said that of all who give gifts, these two were the wisest, for theirs were the gifts of love.”8

 

Brothers and sisters, as you consider what matters most from this day forward, may you determine to accept full accountability for your bodies, your spiritual gifts and how you honor God’s pattern for marriage and family. May the use of the gift of your agency to guard these be among your best gifts of love to your Father in Heaven and our Savior Jesus Christ this season and always. After all, it has been insightfully observed that “What we are is God’s gift to us. What we become is our gift to God.” 9

 

Again I congratulate you on this happy day of your lives! Thank you for allowing me to share in this joyful and significant milestone with you. My prayer is that you will pass the final “final”…the only one that REALLY counts, with flying colors!

 

I leave you with my testimony that the Lord speaks to His servants today to reveal His will because He loves us. His “best gift” was the gift of His Beloved Son, Jesus Christ whose “best gift” to us was His Atoning sacrifice. May we live so as to be worthy of these very “best gifts” is my prayer, in the name of Jesus Christ, amen.

 

1. Doctrine and Covenants 38:30

2. Russell M. Nelson, “Decisions for Eternity, “ Oct. 2013 General Conference

3. Elder David A. Bednar, “We Believe in Being Chaste,” April 2013 Gen. Conf.

4. C.R. Gibson

5. Luke 10:25

6. Luke 10:30-37

7. Handbook 2, (2010) 1.2.3

8. O. Henry, “The Gift of the Magi”

9. Eleanor Powell



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Graduation/2013_12_20_Christensen.htm

 

 

 

 

 

It is such an honor for me to be invited to share a few remarks with you graduates. This is a wonderful season of the year for many reasons. It is wonderful for all of you because you are graduating. It is wonderful because we all take time to reflect on the birth, ministry, and mission of the Savior and all He has done for us. It is wonderful this year for me personally because the season has provided opportunities for deep reflection. One of the many things I have thought about is my experience with BYU-Idaho and the transitions and changes that have occurred for this remarkable institution over the years.

 

I also have reflected on many of the great people who have been part of the process – some who are still involved and some who are no longer with us, like President Gordon B. Hinckley and President James E. Faust. I have had particularly tender thoughts about President Faust and so developed remarks to share with you on this occasion based on a few of the many insights I learned from him.

 

It is important for you to know that President Faust was an attorney by education and training and also that he grew up in rural Utah. Many of the images and metaphors he shared were about things he had observed in nature while growing up or about different aspects of the legal profession.

 

Those of us who work around Church headquarters spend a lot of time in meetings – making presentations, seeking direction, and asking for approvals. From President Faust’s legal background, he kindly reminded us on occasion that when in these meetings, it was better to have a friend in court than a thousand friends out in the courtyard. He truly was a friend of CES and of BYU-Idaho. As a member of the First Presidency and one of the Officers of the Board of Trustees, he occupied a unique position in helping guide this institution as it transitioned from Ricks College into BYU-Idaho more than a decade ago.

 

Another lesson came while President Faust was supervising the work of one of the Church departments. He was instrumental in guiding the preparation of a presentation that was to be shared with the senior brethren. Based on his involvement in developing the presentation, the managing director of the department asked whether President Faust would also like to participate in making the presentation. Because he was a member of the presiding council that would make a decision based on the presentation, President Faust smiled warmly and said, “No. When we are in that setting [where this presentation needs to be made], I will be flying with a different flock.”

 

Using that image from President Faust, I would like to expand on the idea; the concept of flying together in flocks has piqued my interest and has caused me to be more observant of the interaction of different species of birds as they fly. I have tried to learn a little more and think about these interactions.

 

We all know that when geese are flying long distances, they group together and fly in a “V” formation. The purpose of this is many-fold: (1) the synergy of working together as a group creates greater strength for the flock than the sum of the strength that each goose would have individually – the “V” formation actually creates a 50% energy savings that allows the whole flock to increase its flying range by 71%, (2) the geese support each other by honking at one another (referred to as contact calls) whenever one falters or gets out of formation, and also for encouragement to the one on lead, (3) the leadership role is rotated so the lead goose does not have to feel the constant drag and wind resistance by being in the front all the time, and (4) every bird in the formation can see where the flock is going so they can work together to get there.

 

There are many parallels from that image that could apply to all of us as members of families, as members of the Church, and as members of a community. Here are a few for thought: as we move through life, we need to learn to work together so we can be as efficient and productive as possible; working in councils and with teams helps increase our capacity to do more than we could accomplish individually; we need to sustain, support, and encourage each other in our efforts; when it is our turn to fill a leadership role, we should take our turn and not shirk in our responsibilities. But we cannot (or should not) always be out front, we need to learn to be supportive followers as well; and we always need to keep our eye on our long-term goal of eternal life and work together so we all arrive there safely.

 

I also have been fascinated in watching flocks of small birds, such as some species of starlings or different varieties of sandpipers. Rather than flying in some distinct formation, or in an obvious orderly pattern, large numbers of these birds fly together in what are seemingly unorganized swarms. Doing so actually serves multiple purposes. Some researchers have suggested reasons including things such as socialization, facilitating the finding of food, and most importantly, for protection against predators. Many eyes can see much more and warn the others of any approaching dangers.

 

In watching these large flocks of small birds, there appears to be some invisible radar associated with each bird – when one makes the slightest change in its direction, the entire swarm shifts and they all move harmoniously, avoiding mid-air collisions. These birds are responding to a phenomenon called “maneuver waves.” The energy created within the flock caused by individual movements allows each bird to act independently while anticipating changes in the group dynamic at a rate much faster than their individual reaction time would account for.

 

An additional phenomenon has been observed with maneuver waves: as long as the movement brings the birds together or towards a valued goal, they all respond. If a single bird ventures to fly outside of the safety net provided by the flock, exposing itself and the others to potential danger, the rest of the flock resists following in that direction.

 

Again, there are corollaries that are useful for us to consider. Change is inevitable – anticipate it and move with it. Because of your education, hopefully, you are much more intellectually agile and will be able to adjust with changing times. As you do, perhaps you will appreciate this quote attributed to Eric Hoffer, a working-class American philosopher. He wrote, “In a time of drastic change it is the learners who inherit the future. The learned usually find themselves equipped to live in a world that no longer exists.” You have learned how to learn, so make life-long learning an important aspect of your life. Also, if the flock you are flying with is moving towards worthwhile goals and objectives, there is safety in numbers; however, don’t be afraid to fly alone, if necessary. If some bird you are flying with exposes you to danger or tries to get you to move outside of the safety net of the gospel, resist it – don’t go in that direction. As Edward Sanford Martin once wrote, “When 40 million people believe in a dumb idea, it’s still a dumb idea.” Christ said, “I am the way, the truth, and the life,”1 “Come, follow me”.2 Always stay safely on the Lord’s side and you will remain safe.

 

When my wife and I were married thirty-eight years ago, we each wanted to give the other a token gift that expressed our aspirations and devotion for one another – a token to help us focus on what was important and to remain safe. We independently selected the same quote – a familiar Quaker proverb: “Thee lift me and I’ll lift thee, and together we will ascend.” As we all fly along through life (and life seems to fly by faster as you become older), may we look forward and ascend together.

 

As you graduate from BYU-Idaho, you will now move on and begin flying with a different flock, but you will always be counted among the wonderful alumni of this institution. You also will be part of a very elite group. Not only are you among a very small percentage of people in the world who have been able to graduate with a college degree, but you also have had the privilege of attending one of the Church-sponsored universities. As you leave here and fly away to various destinations, remember some of the lessons of nature: don’t forget the safety that comes in staying connected to your flock; draw strength from one another, lift and encourage one another, share the load with one another, and keep your eyes on the ultimate goal of salvation and exaltation; don’t venture outside of the safety net that the Lord has created in order to help you fly safely home.

 

I testify that God will be with you as you “draw near unto [Him].”3 In the name of Jesus Christ, Amen.

 

 

1. John 14:6

2. Luke 18:22

3. D&C 88:63



http://www.byui.edu/Presentations/Transcripts/Graduation/2013_12_20_Clark.htm

 

 

 

 

Before I offer a few remarks to the graduates, I would like to say a word to the parents.

 

Thank you for entrusting your children to us. We love them very much. As I look at you today, I think of all the prayers you have offered on behalf of your children. I think of all the home evenings and family dinners. I think of all the times you sat up waiting for them to come home. I think of your devotion to them and your love for them.

 

I would like to tell you something about your children. The light of the Spirit is in their eyes, and the love of the Savior is in their hearts. These are priceless, spiritual gifts. Your children have worked hard at BYU-Idaho. They have qualified for the blessings of increased faith, testimony, knowledge, and skills that will be of great value to them and their families and to the kingdom of God. They have become disciples of Jesus Christ. The Lord will send your children on His errands in a world in turmoil, and He and His Spirit and His holy angels will go with them.

 

Now, I speak to the graduates.

 

Brothers and sisters, I love you very much. I want to share with you something that happened to me that I hope will be helpful to you as you go forward tonight on your life’s journey.

 

On a recent morning I was studying the scriptures, reflecting on the blessings of the Lord in my life. In that moment a thought came into my mind: you are where you are and what you are, to an important extent, because of your parents. Your parents loved the Lord, served Him with great faith and devotion, and loved you and sacrificed much for you.

 

Your father taught you how to work hard, how to sacrifice for your family, and how to be a good home teacher. He taught you what it means to be a priesthood man, to have both the authority and the power of the priesthood in your service as a father, as a husband, and as a trusted servant of the Lord.

 

Your mother taught you how to do your best and how to cultivate your talents to serve others. She taught you how to put your whole soul into serving the Lord. She taught you how to lead with love and compassion and sacrifice.

 

Your mother and father raised you in light and truth. They taught you how to create an eternal family and build the kingdom of God. It is a precious legacy.

 

As I sat there pondering that message from the Lord, I felt overwhelming gratitude and love for my parents, and for Sue’s parents whose influence on her has been just as profound. I pray that we will have that same kind of influence on our children and our grandchildren. We are creating an eternal family, and we are building the kingdom of God.

 

That is my hope for Sue and me, and it is my hope for you. No matter what your experience has been, I want each of you to resolve today, right now, in this very moment, that you will act with faith in Christ to do everything in your power, use every bit of energy and talent and courage that the Lord may give you, all the days of your life, to raise up your children in light and truth, create an eternal family, and build up the kingdom of God. I know that sooner or later all of you will have that privilege, and I know that the Lord will bless you and magnify you in that effort.

 

The days ahead will be full of wonderful opportunities for you and also great challenges. There is all around us now, and there will be all around us in the days ahead, diabolical shafts in the whirlwind,1 cunning devices,2 lying craftiness,3  subtle deception,4 flattery,5 doctrines of devils, [and] commandments of men.6 These are all designed to tempt you, deceive you, turn you away from Christ, and destroy you and your family.

 

I give you this promise: if you act on the resolve to raise your children in light and truth, create an eternal family, and build up the kingdom of God, great and marvelous blessings will flow into your life. You will put Jesus Christ and His kingdom at the center of your life. You will make and keep sacred covenants in the temple of the Lord. You will seek and receive revelation about your family and everything else in your life. You will obey and serve the Lord, and He will be on your right hand and on your left, and His Spirit will be in your heart, and His angels will be round about you to bear you up.7 You will be happy at home, secure in your covenants, and protected by the almighty power of God.

 

And so I say to you tonight, go forward unafraid with confidence and trust in the Lord Jesus Christ. I know He lives. I know He loves you and has called you to a great work in your eternal family and in His kingdom. His promises are true.

I so testify, in the sacred name of Jesus Christ, amen.

 

 

1. Helaman 5:12

2. Alma 10:13

3. Mosiah 10:18

4. Alma 12:4

5. Mosiah 27:8; Alma 61:4

6. D&C 46:7

7. D&C 84:88
